section.title: Final Payments
section.p: When a loan is paid off with level payments, there is often a need to alter the final payment. This introduces balloon payments and drop payments.

task.p: A loan of 5000 is being repaid with periodic payments of 300. The periodic effective interest rate is 2%. How many payments must be made to pay off the loan?
What is the issue with your answer?

section.p: To deal with the issue you identified, we make modifications to the final payment so that the loan is paid off.

introduction.p: One modification is a balloon payment. This is what we do when we round the number of payments down and make the final payment larger than the other payments.

task.p: What do you need to calculate in order to find the amount that must be added to the last regular payment?
Find the amount of a balloon payment in our example.
The other option is a drop payment. We add an extra payment to the payment schedule, and this payment is a smaller than the other payments.
What do you need to do in order to find the drop payment?
Calculate the amount of a drop payment in our example.

assemblage.title: 🧮 Calculator Tip
assemblage.p: You can find the amount of a balloon or drop payment in your calculator:

li.p: First, enter in all of your loan information and have the calculator CPT N.
Next, round your value of n down, enter the result for N, and CPT FV.
For a balloon payment, add the result to the regular payment. For a drop payment, hit±, enter as PV, enter 1 for N, 0 for PMT, and CPT FV.

introduction.p: (Problem 15) Prince Akeem of Zamunda borrows 75,000 to purchase a car. The loan carries an interest rate of 2.5% convertible monthly. The loan will be paid off with payments of 1643 at the end of each month for 4 years, with a balloon payment at the end.

task.p: Find the amount of the original balloon payment.

Suppose he decides to round up his monthly payment to 2000 (starting with the first payment), and complete his payoff with a drop payment instead of a balloon payment. Find the number of payments of 2000 he will make, and find the amount of the drop payment.

introduction.p: Sometimes a problem will tell you how many payments there are, and that the last payment is larger or smaller than the other payments. In this case, you are given n and the nth payment is either a balloon payment or a drop payment. This means that there are exactly n\! -\! 1 regular payments. If you are not told the regular payments, you can calculate them as usual, but then round to adjust for the balloon payment or drop payment.

task.p: If you round the regular payment down, will the final payment be a little larger or a little smaller than the regular payment? Why?
If you round the regular payment up, will the final payment be a little larger or a little smaller than the regular payment? Why?

statement.p: C.J. Cregg is paying off a loan of 45,000 loan with monthly payments for 3 years. There will be level payments followed by a slightly reduced final payment. The effective monthly interest rate is 3.5%. Find the amount of the final payment.
Part of finding a final payment is finding the outstanding balance immediately following the last regular payment. Do you use the prospective or retrospective method to do this? Why?
